intro: Tetraglochin andina, commonly known as the Andean tetraglochin, is a flowering plant native to the Andes Mountains of South America. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes plants known for their distinctive leaf shapes and often edible parts. The plant is characterized by its upright growth habit and clusters of small, greenish-white flowers that bloom in late spring. Its leaves are typically lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its rugged appearance. Tetraglochin andina is often found in rocky or high-altitude environments, where it thrives in cool, temperate climates.
